channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: As Battle Grows Desperate, U.S. Says It Won’t Push Ukraine Into Talks
item.description: Western officials prepare to meet in Brussels this week amid growing European concerns about the costs and risks of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: North of Kyiv, the Russians Retreated. But the War Never Left.
item.description: In the Ukrainian villages near the Russian border, shells still explode and checkpoints and trenches dot the landscape. And wary civilians live in fear the enemy will return.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olena and Mykola Kalivoshko, both 65, who are from the village of Senkivka, Ukraine, cry as they recount how they fled to nearby Moshchenka because of Russian shelling.

item.title: In South Asia, Climate Change Worries Take On Fresh Urgency
item.description: Hundreds of millions of humanity’s most vulnerable live in South Asia, where rising temperatures make it more difficult to address poverty, food insecurity and health challenges.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Hari Kumar and Atul Loke
item.media:description: Hifjur Rehman, 40, a third-generation farmer, collapsed in a paddy field destroyed by floods in the Indian state of Assam. Mr. Rehman had been worried about how to repay a loan to the bank.

item.title: U.K. Prepares to Send Asylum Seekers to Rwanda
item.description: The plan, a signal by Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government that the country is serious about addressing arrivals coming across the English Channel, has been criticized as unworkable and unethical.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle, Cora Engelbrecht and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arrivals from the English Channel brought ashore in Dover, England, last year. Such crossings have been a growing political problem for Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

item.title: For Its Next Zero Covid Chapter, China Turns to Mass Testing
item.description: Residents in many cities must show negative P.C.R. tests to go shopping or use public services. The policy may hamper efforts to revive the economy.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Workers waiting to show their health codes and proof of a negative Covid-19 test outside a Beijing office building in May.

item.title: Grenfell Tower Fire Families Gather and Ask for Justice
item.description: Survivors, friends and families gathered in London to honor lost loved ones, but a hunger for accountability permeated the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Tuesday was the fifth anniversary of the Grenfell Tower fire that killed 72 people in London. A government inquiry continues, and there have been no charges thus far.

item.title: The Grenfell Fire, 5 Years Later: What Happened, and What Has Changed
item.description: The fire quickly engulfed the apartment building, fueled by cladding now banned. An investigation is continuing. But the families of the 72 who died find accountability slow in coming.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grenfell Tower has been clad in plastic sheeting since the fire in 2017.

item.title: Zimbabwe Court Convicts Reporter for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter, Jeffrey Moyo, is unlikely to spend time in prison, but analysts said the case was part of a wider assault on press freedoms in the country.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Jeffrey Moyo, a respected Zimbabwean journalist who has worked for The New York Times and other international news organizations, said on Tuesday after his conviction, “I’m innocent.”

item.title: Canada and Denmark Settle the Ownership of an Arctic Island After 49 Years
item.description: The two countries agreed to divide an island that sits between Canada and Greenland and defined the area’s international border.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Denmark and Canada signed an agreement Tuesday splitting up the land rights to Hans Island, a small piece of land in the Arctic that sits on the sea border between the two nations.

item.title: Cambodia Sentences Theary Seng and Other Hun Sen Critics to Prison
item.description: Theary Seng, a Cambodian American lawyer, and dozens of other critics of Prime Minister Hun Sen were convicted of conspiracy to commit treason.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Theary Seng, dressed as Lady Liberty, was taken away by the police after her conviction in Cambodia. She has worn a series of extravagant costumes as a form of nonverbal protest.

item.title: What to Know About France’s Parliamentary Elections
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron is looking to secure a strong majority to help him pass bills during his second term, but a reinvigorated alliance of left-wing parties hopes to thwart him.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Campaign posters displayed on Tuesday in Allex, a village in southeastern France.

item.title: Haze Fan of Bloomberg News Released From Chinese Detention
item.description: Haze Fan was taken into custody in 2020 and has not been heard from since. Chinese officials announced last month that she had been freed in January, but many questions remain.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Journalists crowd a press conference for China’s legislature in 2019. News organisations have been facing an increasingly hostile reporting environment in China.

item.title: Indian Cricket Broadcast Rights Fetch a Record Price
item.description: The auction cemented the league’s position among the world’s most valuable sports properties, as a once-staid game has become a commercial juggernaut.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.category: Board of Control for Cricket in India
item.media:description: The Indian Premier League, 15 years old, is the world’s largest cricket league. Shorter matches and star power have helped the sport gain fans in India.

item.title: Iran Suspects Israel Poisoned Two Scientists to Death
item.description: If Iran’s suspicions about the deaths are confirmed, these would be the latest killings in a shadow war that is reaching new intensity as Iran moves closer to nuclear weapons capability.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners at the Tehran funeral in May for Sayad Khodayee, a colonel in Iran’s powerful Revolutionary Guards Corps who was targeted by Israel and killed in a drive-by shooting in Tehran.

item.title: A Link to Besieged Ukrainians Is Cut, as Allies Question Strategy
item.description: The last bridge to the city of Sievierodonetsk fell as street battles raged, and some Western officials questioned Ukraine’s ability to keep resisting the Russian onslaught.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of the Ukrainian regional police force patrolled near the Siversky Donets River, which divides the cities of Lysychansk and Sievierodonetsk, last week.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Sievierodonetsk, Isolated
item.description: The key Ukrainian city lost its last bridge as fighting intensifies.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: How Travelers to Europe Can Deal With the Summer’s Chaos
item.description: Hours in security lines. Canceled flights. Lost baggage. Here’s a look at how you could be affected by travel disruptions this summer and tips on how to prepare.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu

item.title: Moscow Court Orders Brittney Griner Held in Jail for Another 18 Days
item.description: The American basketball star was arrested in February in a Russian airport amid tensions over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and attempts to win her release have repeatedly failed.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, one of the W.N.B.A.’s highest profile stars, has been under Russian detention since February of this year. On Tuesday, Ms. Griner had her detention extended by a Moscow court until July.

item.title: Here’s a look at what’s next after F.D.A. advisers voted to recommend Moderna’s vaccine for children 6 to 17.
item.description: The panel’s recommendation was a key step in the process as federal regulators weigh authorizing the vaccine for those children, but it is not the final say.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid and Johnny Diaz
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Bess Adler for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vial of the Moderna coronavirus vaccine at Altru Chemists pharmacy in Brooklyn last year.

item.title: Chewed and Rolled: How Cats Make the Most of Their Catnip High
item.description: A new study finds that the feline reaction to catnip and silver vine helps to stave off mosquitoes and other bloodsucking insects.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:description: The blossoming catnip plant was found to release 2,000 percent more bug-repelling iridoids when damaged by cats.

item.title: Biden Trip to Saudi Arabia Is Set, but Energy Help Is Not
item.description: The White House formally announced that President Biden would visit the oil-rich kingdom in mid-July despite having denounced it as a “pariah” state after the assassination of a dissident.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden will make his first trip to the Middle East as president from July 13 to July 16, stopping first in Israel and the West Bank before heading to Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Inflation and Price Gouging
item.description: We look at whether “greedflation” is causing higher prices.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Grocery shopping in Manhattan.

item.title: The loss of a final bridge to Sievierodonetsk may hurt Ukraine’s ability to hold its ground.
item.description: The last bridge linking the eastern city with Ukrainian-controlled territory to the west has been destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Smoke rising over Sievierodonetsk on Sunday during intense fighting between Ukrainian and Russian forces.

item.title: Long-Haul Travelers Are Wary About the U.S. Dropping Covid Test Requirements
item.description: Despite worries about greater infection risk on planes, members of the travel industry expected more tourists to seek out travel to and from the United States.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Tourism in Bali, Indonesia, is expected to pick up even more as testing requirements are lifted for return travel to the United States.

item.title: Bosnia on the Brink
item.description: Caught up in a 21st-century stew of ethnonationalism and fake history, the country’s Serbs are now endangering its fragile peace.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Hammer
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Marko Risovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral in Bratunac 30 years after the start of the Bosnian War for four victims whose remains were found following decades of searching.

item.title: Growing Numbers of Girls Resist Genital Cutting in Sierra Leone
item.description: Sierra Leone is one of a few countries in sub-Saharan Africa that have not banned cutting. Now, young women are defying mothers and grandmothers by refusing to undergo the procedure.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: When Seio Bangura, 18, told her family she did not want to participate in a ritual ceremony that involved genital cutting, they rejected her and she moved out.

item.title: How Many Languages Could a Child Speak?
item.description: In theory, a young person could master a broad array of tongues. But there are some inherent limits.
item.dc:creator: Randall Munroe

item.title: Zelensky broke from his usual speech attire to wear a Singapore teen’s T-shirt design.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky virtually addressing participants at the Shangri-La Dialogue conference in Singapore on Sunday.

item.title: Stocks edge lower as Fed decision looms over markets.
item.description: The S&P 500 closed in bear market territory on Monday, down 22 percent from its Jan 3. peak.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson and Daisuke Wakabayashi

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A bear market in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange on Monday.

item.title: Military Clears Crew of Plane That Took Flight as Afghans Fell to Their Deaths
item.description: Crowds of people had surged onto the runway at the airport in Kabul during the final days of the U.S. evacuation of Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: People running alongside a U.S. Air Force C-17 transport plane as it moved down a runway of the international airport, in Kabul, Afghanistan, in August, in 2021.

item.title: On Russia, Europe Weighs Competing Goals: Peace and Punishment
item.description: Arming Ukraine is not turning the tide. Is the answer vastly more weapons, as Ukraine says, or a bitter truce?
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on Monday in Lysychansk, which is under daily attack as Russian forces fight to capture the neighboring city of Sievierodonetsk.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Europe Recalculates on Ukraine
item.description: Plus the Jan. 6 hearings continue and truckers in South Korea strike.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of the Ukrainian regional police force standing next to a destroyed bridge that connected the cities of Lysychansk and Sievierodonetsk last week.

item.title: A top Ukrainian official says urgency is missing in the West’s response to the war.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian gun crew camouflaged an American-made howitzer in the Donetsk region of Ukraine in May.

item.title: Netanyahu vs. Olmert: A Lurid Libel Case Grips Israel
item.description: A sensational legal drama between the two ex-prime ministers, centered on a claim of mental illness, comes as Israel’s year-old government teeters and one of the former leaders eyes a comeback.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu and his wife Sara in 2017, when he was still Israel’s prime minister.

item.title: Bakery in Kyiv Honors Boris Johnson With a Croissant
item.description: A croissant is the latest homage in Ukraine to the British prime minister, who has also had a road named after him in a town near Odesa.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain at 10 Downing Street on Monday.

item.title: The Health Effects of Extreme Heat
item.description: Researchers are drilling down into the ways life on a hotter planet will tax our bodies, and looking for protections that, unlike air-conditioning, don’t make the problem worse.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: Trying to stay cool during a heat wave in Houston this month.

item.title: Authorities Find Belongings of Missing Journalist and Expert in Amazon
item.description: Search crews found clothes and other belongings of the two men who went missing in the Amazon last week. Authorities are also testing blood from a suspect’s boat and human remains found elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:description: Police officers and rescue team members during the search operation for the British journalist Dom Phillips and indigenous expert Bruno Pereira, in Atalaia do Norte, Amazonas state, Brazil, on Sunday.

item.title: Britain Plans to Fly Refugees to Rwanda on Tuesday
item.description: A court refused two appeals Monday, clearing the way for Britain to begin implementing the controversial plan to process and resettle people who crossed the English Channel to get to England.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered outside Brook House Immigration Removal Center on Saturday, protesting a plan to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda.

item.title: Five Years On, Five Lives Shattered by the Grenfell Tower Fire
item.description: After 72 people died in the blaze in 2017, there were vows of reform and accountability. But for those whose lives were upended by the disaster, there have been few answers.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grenfell Tower has been clad in plastic sheeting since the fire five years ago.

item.title: As China Rattles Sabers, Taiwan Asks: Are We Ready for War?
item.description: Ukraine’s stubborn resistance to invasion, and the help that has poured in as a result, has both inspired Taiwan and made it rethink its own military strategy.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin, Amy Chang Chien and Lam Yik Fei

item.title: Russia’s Oil Revenue Soars Despite Sanctions, Study Finds
item.description: Rising oil prices more than offset a decline in export volumes during the first 100 days of the assault on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: The Lakhta Center, headquarters of Russian energy company Gazprom, in St. Petersburg.

item.title: Britain Moves to Scrap Parts of the Northern Ireland Protocol
item.description: The action by the government of Prime Minister Boris Johnson to scuttle the post-Brexit trade arrangement risks a clash with the European Union and upsetting the United States.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces a tricky path pushing the legislation through Parliament. Rebels from his party are threatening to oppose the bill, saying it violates international law.

item.title: Russian Control of Luhansk and Donbas Could Hinge on Sievierodonetsk
item.description: Russian-backed forces already control an estimated 80 to 90 percent of the Donbas, which is a prize for President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke filled the sky on June 8 over the the city of Sievierodonetsk, as intense street fighting took place between Ukrainian and Russian forces.

item.title: Efforts to Form a New Government in Iraq Descend Into Chaos
item.description: The powerful Shiite cleric Muqtada al-Sadr, who controls the largest bloc in Parliament, has directed dozens of lawmakers loyal to him to resign.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Supporters of Muqtada al-Sadr in Baghdad last month. In abandoning negotiations, Mr. Sadr said that he was sacrificing his bloc’s election gains so that a government could be formed.

item.title: U.N. Human Rights Chief Decides Not to Seek a Second Term
item.description: The announcement by Michelle Bachelet, the U.N. high commissioner for human rights, came a month after she was criticized by rights groups for traveling to China.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Michelle Bachelet, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, said Monday she would not seek a second term.

item.title: The Politics of Abortion
item.description: Polls show that support for abortion rights is rising. Will that help Democrats this fall?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators for abortion rights last month.

item.title: Sonia Gandhi, India’s opposition leader, is hospitalized with ‘Covid-related issues’.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Maria Cramer
item.media:description: Sonia Gandhi, left, the Indian National Congress party president, with her son Rahul Gandhi, a former president of the party, during a committee meeting in New Delhi in March.

item.title: The Corpse of a Russian Soldier, and the Cold but Human Urge to Look
item.description: Why does war’s wreckage — the downed helicopters, the destroyed tanks and the dead — draw crowds? A former Marine ponders the question as he stands before the badly burned body of a Russian fighter.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: The remains of a destroyed Russian armored vehicle still containing the burned body of a Russian soldier in a neighborhood damaged during the war in Husarivka, Ukraine, in April.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Gun control in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Joe Biden meets with Senator Chris Murphy of Connecticut, the lead Democratic negotiator on gun reform legislation, a week ago at the White House.

item.title: Tough Questions for West as Ukraine Cities Teeter
item.description: Sievierodonetsk is nearly encircled. Lysychansk may be next. The momentum of the war has shifted, and Ukraine’s allies may soon start rethinking their goals.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Families in the eastern city of Lysychansk, Ukraine, waiting to be evacuated amid Russian bombing Sunday.

item.title: French Elections: Pro-Macron Forces Expected to Prevail After First Round
item.description: The French president’s party and its centrist allies were neck and neck with a left-wing alliance in France’s first round of parliamentary elections.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
item.category: NUPES (Nouvelle Union Populaire Ecologique et Sociale)
item.media:description: Voting in Marseille, in southern France, on Sunday.

item.title: Sweden and U.S. Hold Military Drill on Gotland Island
item.description: The drill took place on Gotland, a Swedish island in the Baltic Sea that was demilitarized after the fall of the Soviet Union, but now again seems a critical military site.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: U.S. troops in Gotland, Sweden, last week.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Encircles Sievierdonetsk
item.description: The last Ukrainian-held city in Luhansk is teetering on the brink.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers are struggling to hold off Russian forces in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: How Bolsonaro Is Using the Military to Challenge Brazil’s Election
item.description: Despite little evidence of past fraud, President Jair Bolsonaro has long raised doubts about Brazil’s electoral process. Now the military is expressing similar concerns.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil attending a military ceremony in April in honor of military pilots.

item.title: Alexander Nikitin, Who Coached a Chess Champion, Dies at 87
item.description: Garry Kasparov was just 10 when Mr. Nikitin took him on as a student. By age 17, with Mr. Nikitin as his coach, he was a grandmaster.
item.dc:creator: Dylan Loeb McClain
item.media:description: Garry Kasparov, left, and Alexander Nikitin in 1978, five years after Mr. Nikitin became Mr. Kasparov’s principal coach.

item.title: The Scene at the Border
item.description: We break down why border crossings are so high and who’s trying to come to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adults and children at Senda de Vida, a sprawling migrant shelter in Reynosa, Mexico, on the banks of the Rio Grande.

item.title: A Restored Painting Recalls the Colosseum’s Christian Past
item.description: The restoration of a wall painting depicting an idealized Jerusalem is a reminder that the Roman monument, known best for gladiatorial combat, was a sacred Christian space for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Francesco Lastrucci for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rome’s Colosseum is best known as a site of ancient gladiator spectacles, but later in its history, it was a Christian holy site.

item.title: Poland Shows the Risks for Women When Abortion Is Banned
item.description: Poland’s abortion ban has had many unintended consequences. One is that doctors are sometimes afraid to remove fetuses or administer cancer treatment to save women’s lives.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Anna Liminowicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Barbara Skrobol visiting the grave of her sister-in-law Izabela Sajbor and her unborn child at a cemetery in Cwiklice, Poland.

item.title: Coming From Separate Worlds in Taiwan, They Collided at California Church
item.description: The 68-year-old suspect in a May mass shooting harbored resentment dating back to his formative years in Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin, Jill Cowan, Shawn Hubler and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Geneva Presbyterian Church in Laguna Woods, Calif., where members of the Irvine Taiwanese Presbyterian Church were meeting when the shooting occurred.

item.title: China Won’t Hesitate to Fight for Taiwan, Defense Minister Warns
item.description: The general said China wouldn’t “flinch from the cost” of defending its claims to the island. He spoke at a Singapore forum where he met with the U.S. defense secretary.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: China will “resolutely smash any schemes for Taiwan independence,” its defense minister, Gen. Wei Fenghe, said at a conference in Singapore on Sunday.

item.title: Momentum in Ukraine Is Shifting in Russia’s Favor
item.description: With the Ukrainians running short of guns and ammunition, and pressures growing on Western governments, Moscow’s fortunes may be rising.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives, neighbors and friends paying respect to a fallen Ukrainian soldier on Saturday in Bucha, Ukraine. At least 100 Ukrainian soldiers are dying every day under intense Russian artillery fire.
